abstract: No theory of language can be properly evaluated without fully worked-out grammars that make use of the theory in handling a complex body of interacting phenomena. In chapter II, I tried to provide such a body of data and analyses from English, against which the theory of Lexical Phonology may be judged. In chapters III and IV, I explore a different language, namely, Malayalam, a Dravidian language spoken in Southern India.
